node.title: heat transfer between two blocks
node.bodyText:
Dear all.
I have some confusion about heat conduction and advection between blocks in MOOSE. I want to calculate a system with an inner heat source, which is a cylindrical structure, with an outer cylinder heating an inner cylinder. I set the initial temperature to 300K. Since I wanted to set both the upper and lower and outer boundary conditions as adiabatic, I didn't do anything in the BCs section. Since the outer block is releasing heat all the time, there shouldn't be a region where the temperature falls below 300K in the whole system, but it turns out that's not the case:

I would like to know where I am setting it wrong, is it possible that there is something wrong with my mesh?
In addition, I also want to ask, if I set the inner cylinder to have water flowing (this is a fluid-solid conjugate heat transfer problem), what conditions do I need to set on the interface? Does heat conduction between solids require no conditions at the interface?
Here are input file and mesh file.
file.zip

Hello
To diagnose if something is wrong with your mesh, you can re-create it using MOOSE mesh generators and see if the result improves.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Mesh/index.html
To understand what you need to make heat flow between regions you need to consider the block restriction of your kernels and maybe if you need to set up interface kernels.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/InterfaceKernels/index.html
Guillaume

Thank you for paying attention to my problem. Are there any three-dimensional solid-solid heat transfer and fluid-solid heat transfer cases in MOOSE?
I re-create mesh by MOOSE mesh generators, but the problem still exists. Here is the results:

I can't understand why the temperature in some places is 300K lower than the initial temperature. The system is adiabatic at the boundaries, and the outer cylinder is releasing heat, so the temperature inside should not drop. Here is the input file using mesh generated by MOOSE mesh generators:
ini_temp = 300 # K

[Variables]
  [./temp]
    initial_condition = ${ini_temp}
  [../]
[]

[Mesh]
  [./ccmg]
    type = ConcentricCircleMeshGenerator
    radii = '3 4'
    rings = '20 10'
    has_outer_square = false
    preserve_volumes = true
    num_sectors = 20 # what does this mean
    smoothing_max_it = 3
  [../]
  [./outer_circle]
    type = SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator
    input = ccmg
    primary_block = 2
    paired_block = 1
    new_boundary = 'outer_bottom'
  [../]
  [./extrude]
    type = MeshExtruderGenerator
    extrusion_vector = '0 0 20'
    input = 'outer_circle'
    bottom_sideset = 'outer_bottom'
    top_sideset = 'outer_top'
    num_layers = 10
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./temp_time_derivative]
    type = INSTemperatureTimeDerivative
    variable = temp
  [../]
  [./temp_diffusion]
    type = MatDiffusion
    diffusivity = 'k'
    variable = temp
  [../]
  [./temp_heat_source]
    type = HeatSource
    variable = temp
    block = '2'
    value = 1e8
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
[]

[Materials]
  [./outer_cylinder]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'rho cp k'
    prop_values = '0.011 300 0.06'
    block = '2'
  [../]
  [./inner_cylinder]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'rho cp k'
    prop_values = '0.01 1500 0.12'
    block = '1'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  num_steps = 100
  dt = 2e-7

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-6

  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason -snes_linesearch_monitor'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       NONZERO'
  line_search = 'none'

  nl_max_its = 30
  l_max_its = 100
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Outputs]
  type = Exodus
[]


The results of the steady state calculations appear to be fine. Because I did not define the outer wall of the cylinder, only outer_bottom, so I set a temperature boundary condition (600K) for outer_bottom, and its output is like this:

Here is steady simulation input file:
ini_temp = 300 # K

[Variables]
  [./temp]
    initial_condition = ${ini_temp}
  [../]
[]

[Mesh]
  [./ccmg]
    type = ConcentricCircleMeshGenerator
    radii = '3 4'
    rings = '20 10'
    has_outer_square = false
    preserve_volumes = true
    num_sectors = 20 # what does this mean
    smoothing_max_it = 3
  [../]
  [./outer_circle]
    type = SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator
    input = ccmg
    primary_block = 2
    paired_block = 1
    new_boundary = 'outer_bottom'
  [../]
  [./extrude]
    type = MeshExtruderGenerator
    extrusion_vector = '0 0 20'
    input = 'outer_circle'
    bottom_sideset = 'outer_bottom'
    top_sideset = 'outer_top'
    num_layers = 10
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./temp_diffusion]
    type = MatDiffusion
    diffusivity = 'k'
    variable = temp
  [../]
  [./temp_heat_source]
    type = HeatSource
    variable = temp
    block = '2'
    value = 1e3
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./inner_dirichlet]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = temp
    value = 600
    boundary = 'outer_top'
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./outer_cylinder]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'rho cp k'
    prop_values = '0.011 300 0.6'
    block = '2'
  [../]
  [./inner_cylinder]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'rho cp k'
    prop_values = '0.01 150 1.2'
    block = '1'
  [../]
[]


[Outputs]
  type = Exodus
[]

In addition, I would like to ask, if two solids contact and conduct heat, but the solids share an interface, what conditions do I need to set on the interface (will MOOSE default to the same heat flux density inside and outside the shared interface)? If the solid has two faces that fit together (no gap between the two faces), what conditions do I need to set? If the fluid transfers heat in the pipeline, the fluid and the solid share an interface. Do I need to set the InterfaceKernel on the interface? If it is a fluid and solid interface with two faces that fit together (no gap between the two faces), do I have to set the InterfaceKernel on the interface?

Hello
I m not sure the INSTimeDerivative is the one to use here. Where did you find a heat conduction example with this?
your density is very small. This means the solid heats up very quickly as well.
The first picture makes me think the boundary conditions are wrong. Which is outer bottom between the inner and outer cylinders?
Finally if the block restriction of the diffusion kernel includes both regions, and they are in contact in the mesh, you do not need to set a special interface condition not let heat flux though.
Guillaume

I think the way MOOSE solves the problem is to combine different terms so that the whole equation can be solved. For example, INSTemperatureTimeDerivative corresponds to ρcp∂T/∂t, so I think adding it to Kernels can add a time term to the equation being solved. Is there any difference between HeatConductionTimeDerivative and INSTemperatureTimeDerivative (they both stand for ρcp∂T/∂t)? Or is there any difference between INSADHeatConductionTimeDerivative and ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative (they both also stand for ρcp∂T/∂t but use automatic differentiation)?
I think a similar problem occurs when I crank up the density, the root of the problem is where there is a drop in temperature in a system that is constantly gaining heat with the same initial temperature.
Outer_bottom represents the bottom of the outer cylinder, and there is an interface between the inner cylinder and the outer cylinder (but I didn't give it a name because I'm not very good at using MOOSE mesh generators). The upper, lower, and surrounding boundary conditions are adiabatic, meaning that no heat is dissipated.
Thanks a lot.

There are differences between those four kernels, but if you have checked the documentation and they add the term you want to the residual then you should be ok.
this
  [./outer_circle]
    type = SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator
    input = ccmg
    primary_block = 2
    paired_block = 1
    new_boundary = 'outer_bottom'
  [../]

named the boundary between block 1 and 2 (eg outer and inner rings) as outer_bottom.  I think outer_bottom is the z = 0 plane,  not this circular boundary. If you made this boundary an adiabtatic boundary that is definitely a problem

I replaced the original with the following Mesh block:
[Mesh]
  [./ccmg]
    type = ConcentricCircleMeshGenerator
    radii = '3 4'
    rings = '20 10'
    has_outer_square = false
    preserve_volumes = true
    num_sectors = 20 # what does this mean
    smoothing_max_it = 3
  [../]
  [./outer_circle]
    type = SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator
    input = ccmg
    primary_block = 2
    paired_block = 1
    new_boundary = 'inner_wall'
  [../]
  [./extrude]
    type = MeshExtruderGenerator
    extrusion_vector = '0 0 20'
    input = 'outer_circle'
    bottom_sideset = 'outer_bottom'
    top_sideset = 'outer_top'
    num_layers = 10
  [../]
[]

I named the interface inner_wall and the bottom of the outer cylinder outer_bottom . But the output is the same as before. I don't think this should be a mesh issue.

Also, when I generate a very fine radial mesh (change rings='20 10' to rings='100 50' ), I have this result:

I don't think Kernels is the reason. I recreated an input file today using ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative, ADHeatConduction, ADMatHeatSource as follows:
ini_temp = 300 # K

[Variables]
  [./temp]
    initial_condition = ${ini_temp}
  [../]
[]

[Mesh]
  file = cylinder.msh
[]

[Kernels]
  [./time]
    type = ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative
    variable = temp
    density_name = rho
    specific_heat = cp
  [../]
  [./diff]
    type = ADHeatConduction
    variable = temp
    thermal_conductivity = k
  [../]
  [./source]
    type = ADMatHeatSource
    variable = temp
    block = 'outer'
    scalar = 1e3
    material_property = const_heat
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
[]

[Materials]
  [./inner_mat]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    block = 'inner'
    prop_names = 'rho cp k'
    prop_values = '11343.7 130 34.8'
  [../]
  [./outer_mat]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    block = 'outer'
    prop_names = 'rho cp k'
    prop_values = '7860 460 46.52'
  [../]
  [./heat_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    block = 'outer'
    f_name = const_heat
    function = '1e11'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  num_steps = 100
  dt = 2e-7

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-6

  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason -snes_linesearch_monitor'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       NONZERO'
  line_search = 'none'

  nl_max_its = 30
  l_max_its = 100
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Outputs]
  type = Exodus
[]

The mesh file(cylinder.zip) and outputs are as follows:

It can be found that there will be temperature distortions at two or three layers of meshes near the interface. What do you think is the cause?

Hello
So for your .msh file the results look distinctively worse. I think there is an issue with that one.
A few potential issues:

mesh isnt conformal at the interface or is conformal but still not properly stitched together
sidesets are not consistently oriented at the interface

For the MOOSE mesh, the results do look bad. I m wondering if it s because you dont have a boundary condition. So the problem is ill-determined, and the solver converges to an unphysical solution.
Guillaume

I set up a DirichletBC with a temperature of 600K at outer_bottom:
[BCs]
  [./outer_bottom]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = temp
    value = 600
    boundary = 'outer_bottom'
  [../]
[]

But it still has problems with its results. The results and output files are as follows:
out_bottom.zip

And I also set inner_wall (interface between inner cylinder and outer cylinder) equal to 600K, the result still has problems:
[BCs]
  [./inner_wall]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = temp
    value = 600
    boundary = 'inner_wall'
  [../]
[]

inner_wall.zip

You mesh cells have a really high aspect ratio right now. Could that be the issue?
Dont place a boundary condition inside the mesh, only on the outside
What is the convergence history for this case? Can you please attach the log here

I reduced the aspect ratio of the mesh, but the result doesn't seem to change anything. The boundary condition I used is that the temperature of outer_bottom is 600K.  As a result, there are two problems, one is that the temperature rises and falls abnormally at the interface, and the other is that it seems that the heat of the heat source is not introduced into the inner cylinder.  I would also like to ask, are there any examples of 3D transient heat conduction and convection heat transfer in MOOSE? I think maybe my input file is written wrong somewhere (though I can't find the error so far and have rewritten it many times). If there are examples of successful thermal conduction and convection heat transfer as a reference, maybe I can find my mistake(I think it should be a relatively low-level error, not a MOOSE bug).
outer_bottom.zip

The following are modifications to the aspect ratio of the mesh：
  [./ccmg]
    type = ConcentricCircleMeshGenerator
    radii = '3 4'
    rings = '20 10'
    has_outer_square = false
    preserve_volumes = true
    num_sectors = 40 
    smoothing_max_it = 3
  [../]

The convergence is very good during the calculation process, the following is the log of the last 5 steps:
Time Step 96, time = 1.92e-05, dt = 2e-07

    |residual|_2 of individual variables:

                       temp: 5.16457
Nonlinear solve converged due to CONVERGED_FNORM_RELATIVE iterations 1

                       temp: 3.27094e+14
      0 Linear |R| = 3.270938e+14
      1 Linear |R| = 9.871416e+00

 1 Nonlinear |R| = 9.930024e+00

                       temp: 9.93002
Nonlinear solve converged due to CONVERGED_FNORM_RELATIVE iterations 1

Hello
This is very not converged. A residual of roughly 1 roughly means the solution changed by 100% between two non linear iterations.
Drop the nl_rel_tol by a lot to make sure you are converging your solutions. This makes a lot more sense now why the results look so odd.
Guillaume

node.title: error about Getting Started : Install MOOSE Conda Packages
node.bodyText: I try to install moose in Ubuntu , but an error occurred during the installation of MOOSE Conda Packages.

Hello
Looks like a conda error to me. Not much we may be able to do about it.
Can you try this instead
conda env remove -n moose
conda install mamba
mamba create -n moose moose-libmesh moose-tools
conda activate moose

Guillaume
I followed your steps, but the following problems occurred
ok run conda deactivate first, then the other steps
if this doesnt work, I'd remove conda completely and re-install
I would not uninstall conda, as it seems to be a channel issue. Please see my answer in this thread.

I just experienced this with a fresh conda installation, and it seems to be an issue with https://conda.software.inl.gov, as switching to idaholab allowed package metadata collection and package resolution. Tagging @milljm.
In the meantime @xiaojbing, please run the following commands individually:
conda deactivate
conda env remove -n moose
conda config --remove channels https://conda.software.inl.gov
conda config --add channels idaholab
conda create --name moose -q -y
conda activate moose
conda install moose-tools
conda install moose-libmesh

Now you should be able to attempt to build MOOSE. Do not forget to run conda activate moose anytime you start a new terminal instance.
If you run into issues, please copy and paste your error into the conversation rather than post screenshots! It helps others who may be encountering the same errors and searching the Discussions forum.
Thank you, I ran the command and the problem has been solved.
I got the same issue with @xiaojbing on Big Sur, but it was resolved by this answer.

The channel is incorrect... Sorry. It should be:
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
I have a fix rolling through the system now: #18630

I have this error and I coudn't solucionate it.
(moose) erodriguez@moccai-11:~$ conda install moose-libmesh
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): failed
UnavailableInvalidChannel: The channel is not accessible or is invalid.
channel name: idaholab
channel url: https://conda.anaconda.org/idaholab
error code: 404
You will need to adjust your conda configuration to proceed.
Use conda config --show channels to view your configuration's current state,
and use conda config --show-sources to view config file locations.

The idaholab conda channel has been closed due to Anaconda's Terms of Service. We are using the https://conda.software.inl.gov/public channel as our primary channel. Please run the following commands to fix your channels and to make sure your environment is set up properly to use the new channel:
conda deactivate
conda env remove -n moose
conda config --remove channels idaholab
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
conda create --name moose -q -y
conda activate moose
conda install moose-tools
conda install moose-libmesh
thanks, it works

node.title: Radiant heat transfer problem
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I have some questions about radiation heat transfer that I need to ask you
Here's my 2D radiation geometry, here's the solid, heat transfer to outer space, and the naming of the edges.Obviously, there is surface radiation heat exchange between ce1 and top1, and there is surface radiation heat exchange between ce2 and top2.

There are two viewfactor calculation programs provided by Moose, one is UnobstructedPlanarViewFactor, the other is ViewFactorRayStudy, UnobstructedPlanarViewFactor is for the calculation of the unobstructed surface, and ViewFactorRayStudy is for the calculation of the surface with obstacles.
The viewfactor calculation method suitable for my problem is ViewFactorRayStudy. I tried to use ViewFactorRayStudy to calculate, but I found that the angle coefficient obtained is like this:

Moose recognized my solid model as a cavity, so there are only angular coefficients at ce1 and ce2. But my model is solid and the rays should be emitted outwards instead of inwards, I don't know if you have any suggestions to solve this problem.

Hello
We only support view factor calculations inside meshed regions currently. So make sure the domain is meshed both inside and outside.
We will have support for external-to-the-mesh view factors next year
Guillaume

node.bodyText:
Hello,
The vtk file was made using dream3D and we wanted to read it with moose and assign each grain ID from vtk to a subdomain_id from moose.
But when I tried to load vtk file with following code:
[Mesh]
type = FileMesh
file = new.vtk
dim = 3
elem_type = HEX8
[]
Error shows up as followed:

Would you please take a look? Thanks.

Hello
Can you try a FileMeshGenerator instead of the old FileMesh syntax please
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/FileMeshGenerator.html
if that doesnt work i recommend installing meshio and converting it to exodus
Guillaume

node.title: Output the wall time taken for each nonlinear iteration
node.bodyText: Is there a way to output to the terminal the wall time taken for each nonlinear iteration?

Hello
Not that I know of directly.
But you can use the perf graph to do that:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/PerfGraphData.html
Just set the section to be the nonlinear solve.
And execute and output this pretty often (on NONLINEAR).
Guillaume

How to output the time often? I saw that the execute_on parameter has a "CUSTOM" option. Can we customize it to output on each nonlinear iteration? Also, by executing on TIMESTEP_END, each time step outputs a two-column table. What do the two columns mean?

the CUSTOM option is going to be some significant C++ coding. You have to create the new flag, but also add all the entry points for this CUSTOM option.
NONLINEAR is alreacdy an execute_on option.
I imagine the two columns are "time in the simulation" and "output of the postprcoessor"
But if you past the output here I can check
yup first is time in the simulation and second is time in the real world
Okay. I have execute_on="NONLINEAR", so I expect the wall time will show after each nonlinear iteration. Why is the time output still at the end of each time step?

the execute on of the postprocessor isnt the same as the console output
I m not even sure we can show you the postrpcoessor that often. But we can print it to a CSV file on nonlinear

node.title: Results of the phase field tutorial
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
I follow the tutorial to get the results. There are many result files from the third step. Why are there so many out.e-s00x files?
Which file is the final result?
Any suggestions or recommendations to fix the problem would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you

These are from the adaptive mesh refinement (AMR). ParaView can open them all at once, just open the s3_decomp_out.e file and it will read all of those and you will see your mesh changing as a function of time in ParaView. If you turn off the AMR, you will only get one mesh file for a serial mesh.
I did what you said and the result was what you said. Thank you!

node.title: Porous Flow Peaceman Borehole: injecting cold CO2 in a doublet
node.bodyText:
I have built a model that reproduces a doublet system where cold CO2 is injected into an aquifer from a first wellbore, and simultaneously fluid is produced at another wellbore. When the CO2 plume reaches the production wellbore, the produced fluid is a mixture of water and CO2.
The initial temperature is 90 °C and CO2 is injected at 60 °C. I am employing the PorousFlow2PhasePS material in non-isothermal conditions. Both injection and production are represented with PorousFlowPeacemanBorehole sinks/sources. The initial pressure is 27 MPa, CO2 is injected at 37 MPa while the fluid is produced at 24 MPa. The reservoir is 100 m thick and gravity is neglected.
I have observed that the pressure at the injection point is decreasing with time: why is this occurring and why is the pressure not constant and identical to the value specified in the PorousFlowPeacemanBorehole command? I am having a hard time understanding the reason behind this.
To inject CO2, I am assigning "sgas" as the variable in the injection PorousFlowPeacemanBorehole. If I change it to water injection "pwater", then the pressure is kept constant and at 37 MPa as specified by the PorousFlowPeacemanBorehole. I suspect it has to do with the relative permeability, which is likely influencing the mobility term in the PorousFlowPeacemanBorehole model, but I do not understand why P_wellbore is changing.
I have attached the files of the simulation, along with a graph showing the evolution of CO2 and water pressure and CO2 saturation at the injection well.
Any suggestion is highly appreciated!

CO2-Injection.tar.gz

Hi @fparisio , i haven't run your simulation yet, sorry, but here are a few thoughts:

the porepressure "at" a peaceman borehole is often not exactly what you specify in the input file.  This is by design.  Here is an explanation....  The Peaceman formulation works by using the analytical solution of the fluid pressure in an element: some further remarks are at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/sinks.html .  More specifically, if your bottomhole pressure is P within an element (you specify P in the PorousFlowPeacemanBorehole), then MOOSE's finite-element solution at the nodes of that element will generally not be P.  Your postprocessor(s) will be equal (or related) to MOOSE's solution directly, not directly to your bottomhole pressure.  The discrepancy you see will be problem dependent.  For example, if the finite element containing your Peaceman borehole is huge, then the porepressure at its nodes will be quite different from bottomhole pressure, while if your finite element is small, the element's nodal pressures will be similar to the bottomhole pressure.  As the finite element size limits to the size of the borehole, the nodal pressures limit to the bottomhole pressure.
the reason why the pressure is changing could be the mobility, since physically it's likely to be getting easier and easier to pump in CO2 (a CO2-saturated reservoir usually has higher mobility).  However, i also suspect that it's a temperature effect.  As you cool the reservoir, the fluids will contract and the pressure will decrease - sometimes quite significantly.  i suggest running a simulation at 90degC and exploring the difference.
Now a question from me: on your figure, why does Pwater = PCO2 when gas saturation = 1.  Usually capillarity would mean Pwater << PCO2 at that saturation.
a

Hi @fparisio

sorry, it's not possible to make the retention temperature-dependent at the moment.  It would fit into the PorousFlow framework well, but we just haven't coded such a thing.  Do you have experimental data for that, by the way?
regarding the out-of-plane question: yes, you can use the Peaceman in that situation, and usually the out-of-plane length is assumed to be 1m (or, equivalently, everything is calculated per unit thickness), both in the conceptual model, and in the PorousFlowPeacemanBorehole.  (You may assume otherwise if you like, but it's unusual).  Often people supply just one point to the PeacemanBorehole (with the "z" direction = zero, for instance) along with line_length=1 and line_direction='0 0 1'.
I'm not sure whether the following suits your problem or not....   You might like to consider another boundary condition for the borehole injection.  For instance, if you're fixing the injection rate, or your injection regime is a known function of porepressure in the rock, then PorousFlowPolyLineSink might be better.  Or, if you're fixing the porepressure, then a DirichletBC might be OK (but remember a DirichletBC is fixing porepressure by injecting/removing a fluid, so you have to be careful which fluid component (Variable) you're applying the DirichletBC to).

a

Hi @WilkAndy, again, thanks a lot for the prompt reply! Here are some comments:


Good question, but I think that for CO2-H2O mixture there is not much data. One simplistic approach is to scale entry pressure $p_a$ with surface tension $s$ as
$$p_a = p_{a0} \frac{s}{s_0}$$
where surface tension $s_0$ and entry pressure $p_{a0}$ are measured at reference conditions. Then, one could assume the variations as a function of temperature and pressure through $s(p, T)$, assuming experimental results (often in the form of MD simulations) for the latter are available as in, e.g., Nielsen et al. (2012). For higher temperature applications, there was an interesting work at the last EGU by Shiga et al. (2022), but I believe the journal paper is not out yet. In any case, it is definetely a relevant and underexplored topic.


Thank you for the suggestion on how to use the PorousFlowPeacemanBorehole in a 2D setting.


I thought about using DirichletBC and fixing pressure, but I am not sure how to compute the extracted/injected masses at a node from the PorousFlowDarcyVelocityComponent module in AuxKernels. Is there a way to compute nodal flow mass rates (volumetric or mass) once fixed a DirichletBC?


References:
Nielsen, L.C., Bourg, I.C. and Sposito, G., 2012. Predicting CO2–water interfacial tension under pressure and temperature conditions of geologic CO2 storage. Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta, 81, pp.28-38.
Shiga, M., Morishita, T. and Sorai, M., 2022. Interfacial Tension of CO2-Water Under Conditions for High-Temperature Geothermal Systems: Prediction and Investigation by Molecular Dynamics Simulation (No. EGU22-6837). Copernicus Meetings.

Thanks for those refs, @fparisio .   One ugly way that you could calculate mass flowrates through a "Dirichlet borehole" is to construct a sideset around the borehole, then use a PorousFlowOutflowBC with a save_in to record the mass-flow through each node on that sideset (and example of save_in is found in test/tests/sinks/injection_production_eg_outflowBC.i). Then use another almost-identical PorousFlowOutflowBC, but with multiplier = -1.  The result is that the residual gets a contribution of +flow-flow (=0) so it is unaffected, but you record the flow in the save_in AuxVariable.  This is quite ugly!
a

Hi @WilkAndy and thank you for the explanation. If I understood correctly, for example for the injection point, I will add two PorousFlowOutflowBC to cancel out the contribution, but record one of them to save it and be able to post-process it as a mass flow rate, correct? I have added what I think is a working example of the injection of CO2 (no capillarity) with a DirichletBC and with PorousFlowOutflowBC for the mass flow rate. Did I make a correct interpretation?
[BCs]
  [injection_dirichlet_saturation]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = sgas
    boundary = injection_node
    value = 1
  []
  [injection_dirichlet_pressure]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = pwater
    boundary = injection_node
    value = 37e6
  []
  [inj_co2_component1]
    type = PorousFlowOutflowBC
    boundary = injection_node
    variable = sgas
    mass_fraction_component = 1
    save_in = co2_kg_per_s
    multiplier = 1
  []
  [inj_co2_component1_mirror]
    type = PorousFlowOutflowBC
    boundary = injection_node
    variable = sgas
    mass_fraction_component = 1
    multiplier = -1
  []
[]

and then add it to the postprocessor as
  [co2_kg_per_s]
    type = NodalSum
    boundary = injection_node
    variable = co2_kg_per_s
  []

@fparisio , you got the concept correct, yet.  There are some caveats:

the PorousFlowOutflowBCs need to be applied to a boundary that contains element edges, not just a single node.  So you should create a boundary in your mesh that surrounds the injection node.  The normal to the boundary should be oriented "outward" (if you get this wrong then you'll just record a negative co2_kg_per_s, which is no big deal).
the variable and mass_fraction_component must be set correctly.  i can't tell from the above snippet whether you've done this correctly, but you probably have.  If the sgas variable is looking after fluid_component = 1 in the Kernels, and the mass-fraction of fluid_component = 1 is all in phase = 1, and the mass-fraction of fluid_component = 0 is all in phase = 0 then you're currently recording phase 1 (probably gas), fluid_component 1 (probably CO2) coming through the boundary.

I'm not so sure of your DirichletBCs.  You need to look at your Kernels to see which fluid_component each variable (sgas and pwater) are looking after.  Also, your PorousFlowMassFraction Materials to see which phase those fluid components correspond to.  The important thing is to physically interpret the DirichletBCs as injecting/removing fluid components in order to satisfy the DirichletBC.  For instance, at the moment the injection_dirichlet_saturation might be fixing sgas = 1 by injecting fluid_component = 1 into the system (which is probably in CO2, and is probably in phase 1, which is probably gas), and the  injection_dirichlet_pressure might be fixing pwater = 37e6 by injecting fluid_component = 0 into the system (which is probably H2O, and is probably in phase 0, which is probably liquid).  The "probably" in the previous sentence can become "definitely" when you explore your Kernels and Materials.

@fparisio , when i say a "boundary" in the above, i mean a sideset in the mesh.  Sidesets needn't be on the actual boundary of the mesh: they can be internal to the mesh, as yours will be.  Sidesets are just a collection of element sides (for 3D elements) or edges (for 2D elements)

Hi @WilkAndy, thank you for clarifying the meaning of sideset.
Concerning the injection problem, the way I set up the example is a consequence of my interpretation of the PorousFlow2PhasePS: if the CO2 is represented by its saturation (sgas), is there a better way to simulate CO2 injection at constant pressure, i.e., as DirichletBC? In the example that I brought it works because with null capillarity pgas==pwater, but could one fix pgas instead at the boundary?

Possibly, you would need to re-phrase your input file (note, i haven't checked exactly how your input file is constructed, so maybe it's perfect now).  Physically, your pumps are injecting CO2 at a fixed pressure.  So you want to fix Pgas with a DirichletBC, and you want the Variable Pgas to be looking after the CO2 component in the Kernels.  Eg, if component = 1 represents CO2, then you want component=1 in all the Pgas Kernels (and you want to make sure the mass-fractions are set to 1 and/or 0 appropriately elsewhere in your input file).   Since your pumps are not concerning H2O at all, you don't want any other DirichletBC.   One of the reasons for the Peaceman approach is that you don't have to worry about all this stuff!

Thanks a lot, @WilkAndy. I also came to use the PorousFlowPeacemanBorehole for the same reasons. I appreciate your help and your comments allowed me to better understand how to simulate the problem in MOOSE.

node.title: Mesh assigned node ID 0 which is different from the (zero-based) Exodus ID -1!
node.bodyText:
I'm having trouble computing a complex model with moose, and the error message is as follows:
*** ERROR ***
Error!  Mesh assigned node ID 0 which is different from the (zero-based) Exodus ID -1!
I think this problem comes from my pre-processing process. I completed the pre-processing on cubit, but I don't know exactly what this error message is pointing to, how do I need to modify it, or redefine the node ID.

Hello
This is coming from the exodus file reader in libmesh. I think it s being confused because the numbering in your exodus file is not as expected by the reader.
Did you renumber node ids? What indexing did you choose?
Guillaume
I'm not renumbering the nodes, there are 30,000+ output nodes,  I think it is hard.
I see that there is a redefinition of node ID in cubit, what should be the starting ID recognized by libmesh.
Try 0

any updates on this?
What is the numbering of the nodes when you open the file with another software than MOOSE

Hi, thank you very much for your attention and sorry for being late. After following your suggestion, I redefine the node number in Trelis, starting from 0. From the performance of MOOSE, this problem solved successfully.

node.title: multiple variables of computeResidual()

node.bodyText: You may want to check out ArrayKernel.C, which works with an array variable having multiple components. This link documents some useful info about array variables: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/variables/ArrayMooseVariable.html.
